Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is the segid for each address

Author: zack#6467
Content: normally a blockchain can't see a unit of time less than 600 seconds, but this one can enforce rules only 2 seconds long.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well it is based on the blocktimestamp submitted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you use a timestamp from too far in the future, the nodes will reject it

Author: zack#6467
Content:
Why does each group only have 2 seconds to stake?
Does that mean their money is only locked up for 2 seconds? or that they have 2 seconds to initialize a bond?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no they become eligible with 2 seconds delay for each segid (on a rotating basis each block)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once eligible, a segid stays eligible for that block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: over time all segids get equal "early" eligibility and "late" eligibility

Author: zack#6467
Content: this is a protocol for choosing the block creator? we need 1 leader?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a difficulty that the stake weighted calculation needs to be below

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the bigger it is and the older a utxo is, the more likely it will be able to stake a block

Author: zack#6467
Content: "stake a block" means you get to be the block creator and gather all the txs into the next block?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: stake a block is just like PoW mining that block, except instead of a hash value, it is based on the stake/age

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so all the tx already need to be in the block you are staking

Author: zack#6467
Content:
you spend coin-age to pay for creating a block.

Usually when people say "stake" they mean that money is locked up in a security deposit for an extended period of time.

Author: zack#6467
Content: so "stake" usually refers to the time period when you are accumulating coin-days, not the moment when you spend coin-days.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i just do a stake and age based calc of a hash and compare it to the diff to see if the block wins

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if more stake is active then blocks come in fast, it becomes harder diff

Author: zack#6467
Content: so, who makes the block, if the staker does not?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: someone must stake a block

Author: zack#6467
Content: so the staker is the block maker?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is like asking who makes the block if there are no miners

Author: FishyGuts#5085
Content: By the looks of it we need a #zack channel.   Thousands of messages here üòÉ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, staking is almost identical to mining

Author: zack#6467
Content: I thought you said that the block is made before anyone stakes it

Author: zack#6467
Content: right so stakers are the block makers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when you mine, you need to create the block to have the blockheader to change the nonce in to mine it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: similarily when staking you need to have the block made already so it can be validated

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well maybe you can do a stake calculation independently of the block construction, but it seems not much point

Author: zack#6467
Content: I was working on some random sampling POS systems like 4 years ago. I am trying to remember the set of attacks that I couldn't solve.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as you need a block to submit if you have a winning utxo.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: stake grinding ?

Author: zack#6467
Content: oh yeah, the random number system is important for random sampling

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the PoS calculation cant rely on anything you can iterate through, or it allows stake grinding, which is a fatal attack against a PoS system

Author: zack#6467
Content:
I think a more fundamental problem is that random sampling is on some level equivalent to a voting mechanism.
Instead of each person having a small voice, they have a small probability of a big voice.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with the PoS64, you want to spread your stake out across 64 addresses, but then you cant really dominate as someone with even a small stake can put all in a single segment

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and which segid you are in is the most important aspect and that cant be changed without losing all coinage

Author: zack#6467
Content:
the attacker would make an alternative version of the full node, and any staker using it would earn like 2% more money than they would earn otherwise.
Once enough people are using the alternative full node, then the attack starts.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with PoS64 actively managing your stake seems to be very effective to boost the percentage of blocks you can get

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the source of entropy is the previous 100 segids

Author: zack#6467
Content: if the attacker has >50% of coin-age using his alternative full node, he can block everyone who isn't participating in the attack from making blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is a cap on coinage of a month

Author: zack#6467
Content:
previous 100 segids huh?
each segid is a number between 1 and 64, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 0 and 63

Author: zack#6467
Content: so each participant can only add like 1 bit to entropy, that sounds like a secure source of entropy.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, i was happy with it, for a while it looked like a big problem

Author: zack#6467
Content: I think an attacker making an alternative version of the full node is a pretty serious vulnerability

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what does this alternate node do? it stillneeds to follow consensus

Author: zack#6467
Content: it follows consensus exactly normal, until like 60% of the staking power is using the attacker version

Author: zack#6467
Content: at that point it censors the 40% who did not participate in the attack.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, so people dont know they are running this?

Author: zack#6467
Content: and uses censorship to do a soft fork to make arbitrary changes

Author: zack#6467
Content: they just know that the alternative version of the full node pays 2% more

Author: zack#6467
Content: you could warn them, but even if they know it is an attack, the nash equilibrium is to fall for the attack

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well if the majority of stake decides to run the attacker version, then it seems that is the new chain

Author: zack#6467
Content: haha

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 100% PoS does seem very vulnerable, we dont recommend it

Author: zack#6467
Content: Well, Ive always wanted to do a malicious takeover of a blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a balance between PoW and PoS

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can try to take over the BEER chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, that isnt PoS...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if people are running a rogue version, why wouldnt it just steal all the privkeys?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and how does it pay 2% more?

Author: zack#6467
Content: the attacker is paying the bribe

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or it is just a ploy to get people to run it?

Author: zack#6467
Content: if the alternative version just steals their private key, then the nash equilibrium is not to fall for the attack.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i see, it is a real 2%, then yes a lot of people just might use it, but it couldnt get any large installed based without being noticed

Author: zack#6467
Content: getting noticed doesn't matter. the nash equilibrium is still that the attack succeeeds.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what about if it is 50% PoW/50% PoS

Author: zack#6467
Content: im not sure. it depends on the specifics of how you are meshing the two

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PoW diff adjuster

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the actual percentage of past 100 blocks is compared to the desired percentage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if too much PoW, the diff is increased for PoW, if not enough, the diff is lowered

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: overall the normal blocktime based diff adjustment happens based on all the blocks

Author: zack#6467
Content: so if you took over the PoS portion, and stopped making PoS blocks, then the block rate would just keep getting slower?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will adjust the diff to make it easier to make blocks to try to keep the blocktime, but then PoW goes over the desired percentage and blocks slow down

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: likely the chain could get stuck if everyone just stopped staking

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just the PoW required would be enormous

Author: zack#6467
Content: if the difficulty got too high, and then I suddenly started making PoS as fast as I could, then maybe 80% of blocks would be PoS for the next 100 blocks?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sure, you can play games to get some fast blocks for a short time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but once the past 100 blocks goes below the target the PoW becomes easier and easier

Content: @zack While I do think you have some wrong base notions and I imagine that I matter as little to you as I do to most of the rest of the world, I want it to be said that I am glad you reached a point where you're questioning to actually learn and understand more and this space would be a dam'd sight better as a whole if more folks would do just that.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
sometimes there are ways to oscillate systems like this to earn more profit.
If there is a part of the cycle where mining difficulty is a fraction of what it should be, then that means miners are way over-paid.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure you could actually get it to 80% with PoS. for PoW if you go from one core mining to a few Msols, it will get a lot of blocks until things adjust

Author: zack#6467
Content: and during the other part of the cycle, only altruists will mine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but with it being half PoS, it is just a matter of staking for half the blocks

Author: zack#6467
Content: so you could start the cycle pumping, then only mine during the profitable part of the cycle.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and perfectly coordinate 3 different chains so you can always be making max profits!

Author: zack#6467
Content: you could do the bribery attack to control the majority of PoS blocks

Author: zack#6467
Content: haha, yeah, if you get multiple at once it is much more effective

Author: zack#6467
Content: that way there is no down time for miners

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it all sounds so easy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but in reality the randomness would get in the way

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and these are by and large lower value chains

Author: zack#6467
Content:
if it is 50-50 pow/pos, and you can do a bribe attack to control 80% of the PoS. 
What would stop you from completing the rest of the attack?

Author: zack#6467
Content: how does randomness matter?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sure if you can get 80% of the PoS blocks, 40% of total stake running your version, likely you own that chain

Author: zack#6467
Content:
and we already know it is the nash equilibrium for stakers to participate in the attack.
So it seems inevitable that it will eventually happen.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems such a long winded attack though

Author: zack#6467
Content: I spent a lot of time working on PoS, but Amoveo is PoW.
